index.title: A PhD student at Université Laval
index.aboutText:
I am a PhD candidate in Computer Science at Université Laval
                            (Canada) specializing in AI-driven software architecture and distributed systems.
                            My research focuses on developing intelligent approaches for automated microservices
                            decomposition, resulting in four peer-reviewed publications in leading journals and
                            conferences including Empirical Software Engineering (EMSE) and Information and Software Technology (IST).
                            Previously, I completed a Master's degree in Smart Systems from the National School of Computer Science (Tunisia),
                            with a focus on deep learning applications. Fully bilingual in English and French,
                            I combine theoretical expertise in machine learning with strong practical experience in
                            cloud-native technologies (Kubernetes, Docker), distributed systems design, and
                            Machine Learning frameworks (PyTorch, Transformers).
index.researchText:
While microservices architecture has proven effective for large-scale applications due to its modularity and cloud compatibility, migrating from an established monolithic system to a microservices architecture remains an expensive and challenging process. The critical decomposition step of partitioning the monolith's components into target microservices has been cited as the main obstacle.
My thesis focuses on studying automated decomposition and refactoring approaches for the purpose of modernizing the migration and modernization process of software architectures. I introduce AI-based approaches ranging from evolutionary algorithms to LLM-based representation learning to improve the efficiency of decomposition approaches and provide better microservices recommendations. In addition, this thesis introduces an approach to automatically refactor monolithic interactions into RPCs using a combination of Gen AI models and meta-modelling methods.
index.researchInterests: Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Deep Learning, Microservices, Code Refactoring, Cloud

courses.cloud: GLO-7008: Cloud Native Applications and DevOps

courses.algo: Algorithms, Data Structures and C Programming

prep.school: Preparatory Institute for Engineering Studies of Tunis (IPEIT)

monomorph.description1: An LLM-based agentic tool that fully automates the refactoring of monolithic Java applications into microservice architectures. Built on research from
monomorph.description2: MonoMorph bridges the gap between decomposition planning and executable microservices by automatically analyzing codebases, determining optimal refactoring strategies, and generating gRPC-based communication infrastructure while ensuring consistency and correctness of the newly generated microservices.

microanalyzer.description: A collection of static analysis tools in various programming languages (Java, C#, Python, JavaScript, Ruby, Go). As part of a larger research paper, this project implements a set of parsers that extract code snippets in microservices based applications for multiple programming languages.

rldec.description1: This project is an implementation of the RLDec decomposition approach as described in the paper
rldec.description2: RLDec is a decomposition tool that analyzes the source code of a monolithic Java application and suggests the recommended microservices for each class in the system using a Deep Reinforcement Learning based method. The approach was implemented mainly Using PyTorch and Ray-RLlib, a reinforcement learning library that provides a high-level API for distributed reinforcement learning.

hydec.description1: This project is an implementation of the HyDec and HierDec decomposition approaches as described in the papers:
hydec.description2:
HierDec is a decomposition tool that analyzes the source code of a monolithic Java application through static analysis and a TFIDF based pipeline and suggests the recommended microservices for each class in the system using a hierarchical version of the DBSCAN algorithm.

HyDec is an extension of the HierDec approach that combines the static analysis results with the dynamic analysis results to improve the quality of the decomposition.

The current implementation is a generalization of the approach proposed in HyDec enabling the use of various representations of the source code (with or instead of the static and dynamic analysis results). It includes the default configurations which correspond to the HyDec and HierDec papers.

msextractor.description1: This project is an implementation of the MSExtractor decomposition approach as described in the paper
msextractor.description2: MSExtractor is a decomposition tool that analyzes the source code of a monolithic Java application and suggests the recommended microservices for each class in the system using the evolutionary algorithm IBEA (Indicator-Based Evolutionary Algorithm).

sunflower.title: Automatic classification of sunflower seeds based on X-ray images
sunflower.description: This project was done as part of my end of studies internship at Vilmorin Mikado. The goal was to develop a machine learning model that can classify sunflower seeds based on X-ray images. The project involved 3 main parts:
sunflower.parts:
• Developing a segmentation module to extract the seeds from the X-ray images using traditional image processing techniques
  • Building the classification module which included researching the best model to use, data preprocessing, and fine-tuning the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model on the DICOM image data
  • Developing a user-friendly interface to allow the users to upload the images, review them, edit them, get the classification results and fine-tune the generated results

foodies.description: This project was done as part of my studies for the course "Design and Development" where we had to develop a software from inception to deployment. This project is recipe recommendation system for Tunisian cuisine using ingredient data. The application utilizes data mining techniques to process the ingredients and machine learning techniques to build the recommender and a Django webapp to host the system.

lecturer.title: Lecturer and Teaching Assistant
lecturer.department: Department of Computer Science and Software Engineering

courses.glo2100: Algorithms and Data Structures for Engineers

lecturer.descriptionLecturer:
As a lecturer, my responsibilities involved delivering engaging and well-structured
                                        lectures, designing and creating practical work assignments, and developing comprehensive
                                        exams to assess student understanding. I also provided constructive feedback
                                        and contributed to curriculum development.
lecturer.descriptionTA:
In my role as a teaching assistant, I led laboratory sessions, guided students
                                        through practical work, and ensured they grasped key concepts effectively.
                                        I also contributed by correcting exams and assignments, offering detailed feedback,
                                        and supporting the lecturer.

cognira.title: Junior Data Scientist
cognira.summary: Retail time series forecasting analysis and data visualization.
cognira.tasks:
• Weekly discussions with the client about the forecasting results and the impacted sales.
  • Evaluating the performance of the forecasting systems and optimizing their hyper-parameters.
  • Daily analysis of the recent sales and forecasting data.
  • Developing and improving the internal analysis tools.

hq.title: Data Science Research Intern
hq.summary: Time Series Forecasting for monthly HQ specialist workloads.
hq.tasks:
• In this internship, I worked with a team within the Hydro-Quebec Research Institute (IREQ). The project I worked on involved researching a time series forecasting model for the workload done by HQ specialists across Quebec. My tasks involved:
    • Analyzing the historical data in order to extract meaningful insights and present them to the team.
    • Refactoring and improving the architecture of the project.
    • Building a separate yearly forecasting model.

vilmorin.title: Research and Development Intern
vilmorin.summary: Automatic classification of sunflower seeds diseases based on X-ray images.
vilmorin.tasks:
• End of Study Internship: Executing the project from initial concept and planning to design, development, testing, and final deployment.
  • Designing a Deep Learning model that can classify the defects in sunflower seeds.
  • Processing and segmentation of DICOM images (X-ray) that includes batches of sunflower seed samples.
  • Building a GUI for improving the user experience and productivity.
  • Integrating the image processing and classification module into the GUI.

teamwill.title: Software Engineering Intern
teamwill.summary: Building automated forecasting and database analysis microservices.
teamwill.tasks:
• Developing a microservice that exports and models relational databases into graph databases.
  • Building a prototype microservice that enables automatic forecasting or clustering.

logidas.title: Software Engineering Intern
logidas.summary: Developing a tool for analyzing, parsing and exporting Paradox databases.
logidas.description: Developing a tool for analyzing, parsing and exporting Paradox databases. The tool was integrated into the company's ERP product.

eje.title: Project Lead
eje.name: ENSI Junior Enterprise
eje.tasks:
• Led the development of internal projects (such as our website) that involved the collaboration of multiple students.
  • Played an active role organizing events and handling partner logistics.

gdg.title: Executive Board member
gdg.tasks: Organizing local branches for Coding Competitions.

yfs.title: Instructor for middle-schoolers
